item.title: Parent and Adolescent Influences on Each Other’s Health Behaviors: A Cross-Sectional Examination of a Dyadic Theory of Planned Behavior in a U.S. National Sample
Behavioral compensation before and after eating at the Minnesota State Fair
Reducing sugar in coffee while maintaining enjoyment: A randomized controlled trial
item.description: Figure 2 from Lenne & Mann (2017). Sugar-use by condition at baseline (before the intervention), one month after the intervention ended, and six months after the intervention ended. The left panel shows the frequency of consumption of sugar-free coffee. The right panel shows the percent of cups of coffee that were consumed sugar-free. Mean and standard error are depicted at each time point. All responses are plotted.

item.title: Modeling parents’ and teenagers’ impact on each other’s eating and physical activity using the Theory of Planned Behavior.
